hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaydah from Jabir ibn Zayd from Umar ibn al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him): Umar said to his helpers: 'Do not take the finest animals of people, nor the full-uddered ones.' Al-Rabi' said: The finest ones are the best choices, and the full-uddered is one with a large udder. Additionally, Abu Ubaydah said: The Prophet ﷺ forbade a man from deliberately selecting the worst of his wealth to give as Zakat. He said: 'The best of you in the sight of Allah is he who brings forth the best of his wealth.'

Abu Bakr said: There is no hardship for the one who is called from all these gates. So will someone be called from all these gates, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Yes, and I hope you will be among them. Al-Rabi' said: The meaning of 'pairs' here refers to things like two sandals or two shoes, and whatever comes in the form of pairs like them.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaydah from Jabir ibn Zayd from Anas ibn Malik: Abu Talha was the wealthiest of the Ansar in Madinah in terms of palm groves. The one dearest to him among his properties was Biraah, which faced the mosque. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to enter it and drink from its water, which was pleasant. Anas said: When this verse was revealed 'You will never attain piety until you spend from what you love' (Surah Al-Imran 3:92), Abu Talha said: Indeed, the dearest of my properties to me is Biraah, and it is charity for Allah. I hope for its reward and its treasure with Allah. So place it, O Messenger of Allah ﷺ, wherever you wish. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said to him: 'Well done, well done! That is wealth that brings its owner to Paradise. I have heard what you said, and I think you should give it to your relatives.' Abu Talha said: I will do so, O Messenger of Allah. So Abu Talha distributed it among his relatives and cousins.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaydah from Jabir ibn Zayd from Abu Hurayrah from the Prophet ﷺ: 'The best charity is the maniha that is productive, it comes back in one vessel and leaves in another.' Al-Rabi' said: The maniha is a she-goat, and the productive one is one with much milk. [Additionally, narrated by Abu Ubaydah from Jabir ibn Zayd from Anas ibn Malik]: Abu Talha said to Um Sulaim: I have heard the voice of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ weak, recognizing hunger in it. Do you have anything? She said: Yes. She brought out barley loaves, then took her veil and wrapped the bread partially in it, hid it under my arms, and covered me partially with it, then sent me to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. Anas said: So I went and found the Messenger of Allah ﷺ sitting in the mosque with people. I stood, and he said: Did Abu Talha send you? I said: Yes. He said: With food? I said: Yes. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said to those with him: Get up. Anas said: So we set out until we came to Abu Talha and I informed him. Abu Talha said: O Um Sulaim, the Messenger of Allah ﷺ has come with the people, and we do not have food to feed them. Anas said: So the Messenger of Allah ﷺ entered and said: O Um Sulaim, what do you have? So I brought that bread. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ ordered it to be broken up, and Um Sulaim poured her ghee over it, which made a sauce for it. Then the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said something over the food, then said: Let in ten. They entered, ate until they were full, then left. Then he said: Let in ten. They entered, ate until they were full, likewise, until all the people ate, and they were seventy men.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaydah from Jabir ibn Zayd from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri: Some people from the Ansar asked the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, so he gave them. Then they asked him again, and he gave them three times until what he had was exhausted. Then he said: Whatever good comes with me, I will not withhold it from you. Whoever refrains from asking, Allah will grant him independence. Whoever seeks self-sufficiency, Allah will enrich him. Whoever is patient, Allah will grant him patience. And no one has been given a gift better and more comprehensive than patience.
